reviewText:
Catan is a fun board game. It's a fun Android/iOS game. It is a HORRIBLE PC game. It crashes pretty much all the time at random. A dice roll can crash the game. Hitting 8 victory points can crash the game. Trading resources can crash the game. Anything at all can crash the game!

The campaign is unplayable because just trying to play certain levels crashes the game.

I'm really serious about all these crashes. It's no joke. What is a joke is that I can run Tomb Raider, Bioshock Infinite, Metro Last Light, etc on max settings (or close enough), but I can't run a board game.

If the game was playable, it would probably be awesome. I have the Android game also that plays just fine. Playing as a video game eases all the resource management and whatnot from the board game. The game keeps track of everything for you.

The AI cheats hardcore also. I can the AI being intelligent and trying to stop the human player(s) from winning when victory is near, but you can be at 9/10 victory points with the AI at 3/10, and suddenly no one will ever roll numbers you can use again. The game replaces difficulty with implausible dice roll outcomes. The computer also constantly offers horrendous trades and won't accept fair ones. If you have one brick and no source of brick, they will routinely try to take your only brick in exchange for a sheep you already have 8 of. Robber rolls also seem to occur more frequently when the human player(s) are past the hand size limit. It isn't impossible to beat the AI. It's just frustrating to wait turn after turn after turn and see it rolls nothing but 3s and 5s because you don't have 3s or 5s.

If you like Catan, just get the mobile/tablet game. There's no online mutliplayer in any version of the game which is sad. There's a major trend in board games coming to PC/mobile that don't have mutliplayer. There is hot seat multiplayer which works fine. I play with a friend regularly on my Android device. It's good times.

reviewText:
Huge fan of Catan, so I thought I'd take a chance on this. Unfortunately, I was very disappointed.

Pros:
Visually it looks good, or at least enough for a board game based on Catan.

It handles all the rules for you so you don't have to stop the game and engage in debates. Not that you would with this version anyway (more on that later), and it includes all the scenarios and a map editor (though I haven't tried that yet).

Cons:
Controls are lacking. The map can be squirrelly to navigate. If you're using a touch-screen it's nigh-impossible. When using my Windows 8 touchscreen laptop I kept flying off into some unknown corner of the map and tapping on buttons would cause other buttons to active. The interface isn't very intuitive and it doesn't have pop-up text to help with identification.

Buggy. As others have pointed out, it's buggy and prone to crashing.

No multiplayer. This is probably the biggest negative. It's on Steam. Why not let you play with other players who own the game? I'm guessing they don't want competition to their own multiplayer subscription site, but then why even bother with this version in the first place?

Graphics options. While the graphics look decent, the lack of resolution options is very disappointing.

TL;DR: The game isn't worth the asking price. I picked it up on sale and don't completely regret it simply because I still fire it up every now and then just get a Catan fix when I can't round up a couple more players for the board game, but otherwise this one just sits in my library collecting virtual dust. The biggest disappointment is how close they are. If they fixed the bugs, tweaked the interface, and added multiplayer through Steam, it would instantly be a classic.

reviewText:
Giving this game a bad note wasn't easy. If you could buy it for a dollar or two I would probably note it positive but I don't find it worth 15 euro.

First, PC version alone:
No decent tutorial. You need to download instructions to the tabletop Catan or figure it out by trial and error. That's the first frustrating thing at the beginning.
The game can crash. It doesn't happen a lot but it is still possible, so it would be wise to save it as much as you can.
When you want to build a road or a ship at the bottom of the map you might not be able to do it as the map is fixed there and the right bottom menu covers the map.
However, changing view from computer graphics to a tabletop is a pretty nice thing. It can be helpful if you don't have a damn good graphics. There're also some options to choose from and it makes the game more dynamic.

Second, game mechanics:
If you don't like games based primarily on luck, you may not want to buy Catan. It's quite engrossing and needs some allocation of resources but so far I've found the very beginning the most strategic part in Catan. The rest is highly dependable on the dice throws. You may get resources or not. Neither the trade is the best part there. In the worst scenario you end up without resources needed and being robbed all the time by other players while you're trying to save some to build anything. Also, starting first you get more chances to use the best spot on the map. The next turn goes counterclockwise but still the first is the first.
Basic game is quite boring. Nothing much happens there. I found Cities and Knights to be the most interesting map to play. However, it makes the game somehow easier if you manage to get to the dragons in the first turns (you just need to kill a couple of dragons to win the game).

Still, it can be fun but I find it more like a facebook game than a hard strategical/tactical one. Just a nice way to kill some time. So, if you can find the game on sale, you can give it a go. I wouldn't pay for that much though.

Short version: 17%This version of Catan has somehow managed to be so bad that it could hurt the game’s reputation more than a political smear campaign.

Long version:A video game adaptation of a board game can be a good alternative to practise some when no friends are available for the original. That happens often with something as long and complex as the original Settlers of Catan, a famous table-top, turn-based, resource management strategy game.
Sadly, this version is utterly incapable of fulfilling that role.

If you bought this game to learn Catan, you are out of luck. There is no tutorial, the game just expects that you already know the roughly 30-page rule book in every detail by heart. And even if you do, good luck figuring out which elements of the dreadful user interface represent what action.
Then there is the AI. The lack of online multiplayer can be forgiven if the computer plays decently. It doesn’t. It doesn’t even try to win, just gangs up on you to hinder you in every possible way. And even if you gain advantage, it magically starts rolling sevens to rob all your resources, essentially rendering you helpless.

Add in a dumb “storyline”, bad voice acting, dreadful visuals (why did it have to be in 3D in the first place?), and constant crashes to turn this into one of the worst board game adaptations of all time. Yes, worse than Bible Buffet.

reviewText:
I am a long time fan of the Settlers of Catan series.  I've been looking for a good PC version so that I can play around without having to bust out the entire game board or even have to have others to play with.  Unfortunately, games like this only see mobile support for tablets and phones for some reason as though the PC is some kind of forgotten relic.  There are several different PC versions of Settlers that I have found, but there seem to be several common elements between them that make the games difficult to impossible to play.  This version is more towards the difficult end of the spectrum with its flaws.

VISUAL: The game looks nice.  That's it, nice.  It's a PC version of a simple looking board game.  I've seen virtual chess games with more interesting depth to them than what we seem to get out of Catan for some reason.  Cities and Knights in particular is underwhelming, it's often difficult to tell what rank the available knights are or if they're activated or not which can greatly impact game play.  You can choose between a regular Catan board or a...well, let's call it what it is: a visually busy version.  The second form of the board has extra animations for the board to illustrate the tiles but the settlements and roads get lost in the mix.  The other negative in this column is the 'road building' zoom.  Whenever you want to build a road, the game slams your face into the board and does not allow you to overlook the board to make sure of where you are in regard to others.  It's a poor mechanic choice but I believe it can be turned off in the menu.

The in game menus are broken as well, if you are given the option to pick a free resource and it's not your turn, you can't see your hand to know what might benefit you most.  I often have a general idea of what I have but without knowing exactly what is in my hand it's an annoying mechanic that should be fixed.  I would also bring up that the game's aspect ratio is limited to the point of annoyance.  Unless you play it full screen, the menu options along the bottom may range from barely visible to unclickable which is a pain since Enter and Esc do not act as an accept and cancel feature as they do in most other computer programs I've encountered.

AUDIO: The game, as far as I have heard, has one song.  Just one.  Not a loop, it has a clear beginning and end to it and it plays over and over.  If there are more than the one track, the songs are indestinguishable from one another.  Not a huge loss, I just turn the music off and put on somehting fitting of my own collection.

The sound effects in the game are simple but fitting for the actions.  I wish they had done something with voice acting to make the computer players feel more life like instead of the simplistic route of uninteresting portraits.  If I could at least switch out the portraits or add my own then I would have been happy with that too.

GAMEPLAY:  As other reviews have no doubt mentioned, this game is unstable.  It crashes frequently.  The obvious workaround is to save often though I haven't had any problem with the game's autosave feature.  The few times it crashed for me I was able to simply reload and continue from the same turn.

Getting back to what I mentioned at the beginning of this review with what all of the PC versions of Catan seem to have in common.  The AI cheats to create the illusion of difficulty.  This seems inescapable in this game for some reason.  If the human player gets close to winning, the die rolls suddenly favor the computer as well as all card draws.  In all of the games I have ever played of Catan, I have never seen any game take that sudden and blatant of a shift so that a player with three points can gain over a player with more than ten.  The computer players suddenly gang up on the human player, refusing trades, stacking the decks and loading the dice.  I've had a few games where the computer gets whatever cards they need in spades while I'm left with nothing.  The computer players will even choose to block and steal from the human player when it would be substancially more advantageous to attack each other.

Another element that is annoying to those of us who haven't memorized every last card in the game is when a computer player plays a card.  The name of the card is shown but not the effect and often not even who is being affected or how.  If you know the entire game by heart then you will be fine but this can be frustrating for anyone who is just learning the game and doesn't have a hard copy on hand to flip through to find out what just happened.

There is no online multi-player for this version, there is only a hotseat mode.  That suits me fine, but it may be a clinching feature for others.

Now, why in the name of wood for sheep am I reccomending this game if there's so much to complain about?  Because it's the best version I've seen yet for PC.  Yes, the game is flawed and unstable, but it is the best PC port of this game I have found so far.  Its problems are tolerable which is saying a lot for a game like this.  Between the game having both Cities and Knights and Seafarers and supporting at least a hotseat multiplayer game, it's the best Catan for PC version I've ever seen.  If you don't like working with games that can be unstable at time then you probably won't enjoy this.  But if you are willing to suffer a little for a game like this then it's still fun.  I would wait for a good sale but I would definitely consider adding this to your library.

reviewText: Game with great potential. I would love it, if only I could play it. Sadly after few minutes of gameplay it always crashes! Don't buy it if you value your nerves and money

A very good port of the board game, plays well and stays true to the game and expansion packs. However, In what I consider to be a cash-grab by the company, there is no other OS options on steam except for Windows. Sure I could go buy it on the mac store, but why pay another $15, when it should have the option for different OS's. Other games can play multi-platform, this should as well.

Difficulty setting and currently winning the game should not affect the chance of the dice. But if its on hard difficulty and you are winning, the AI almost always roles a 7 and will steal all your resources. If this one thing could be changed, true dice randomness, then I could recommend the game because otherwise its great.

I've just beaten both campains which are fun and surprisingly long (in a good way though the Cities & Knights boards are the same as the Seafarers boards just different rules). The story that goes along with it is also quite entertaining for consisting entirely of 2 minute interludes between new board setups. The different rule sets during the campaign are interesting and produce opportunities for using multiple strategies.

The game does crash frequently (which is ridiculous for such a simple game), but regular saving mitigates that frustration adequately. Also I suspect the random number generator used to control the dice rolls generates numbers in batches because the rolls after loading from a save because of a crash were consistent with the original rolls before the crash. This means that (as long as you save) the game doesn't change because of a crash, you just have to play the last couple hands over again with the same dice rolls. There is another quirk that isn't quite as easly overcome. The game zooms in on regions of the board when you execute certain actions (build a road or a ship) and doesn't let you zoom out or move the camera until after you complete your action.  Later in the campaign, one of the rule sets requires you to strip the dice roll number from an old area whenever you find a new area (essentially retire an old game space and replace it with the new location). The locked auto-zooming means you can only select areas to retire from those currently in view of the camera (even though the rules would allow you to select areas outside of the current camera view). I couldn't find a work around for this and was forced to just incorporate this quirk in my game plans. It never cost me a win but it is another example of poor programming. Lastely, the game would sometimes get ahead of itself, meaning that after an AI dice roll, the game would execute the next AI player's dice roll before conveying the actions the first AI player executed. The game usually caught back up with itself by the next dice roll though occationally it did crash. I would suggest saving anytime you see this behavior.

Ultimately, the game is old enough now that you can often find it on sale very cheap or as part of a bundle and the flaws in the software, while a damper, can be worked around enough, or are minor enough when they can't be worked around, that they didn't outweigh the fun and challenge of Catan (which is a wonderful physical board game as well that I would recommend w/o hesitation).

If you want a computer version of settlers of Catan, look no further. However, three main problems exist:

1. This will crash. A lot. Sometimes this will be from just starting the game, sometimes this will be from trying to trade resources or perform simple tasks. Reloading will solve any problems, but this can be very annoying and happens on average at least once per game. EDIT: Most bugs seem to be tied to not letting animations for trading or resource gathering complete. Wait every single time until you're sure the animation completes before proceeding. Otherwise, the game can crash, you can cheat, or the game will become unplayable.

2. AI is a little buggy and can sometimes just hoard upwards of 30 resources when spending virtually any would win them the game. This happens about every fourth or fifth game. The AI is beatable, despite what some others claim.

3. If you're new to Catan, I would recommend skipping the game's tutorials and reading about how a turn works online. The tutorials are in the help menu and are short, episodic, and do not have any line dividing the basic game from the expansions included. This will confuse new players unfamiliar with just the basic rules.

Overall it's not terrible, but it could be better. It's clearly unfinished and not thoroughly tested though and not really worth spending money on.
